The government in Tokyo lodged a protest and its top spokesperson, Chief Cabinet Secretary Minoru Kihara, urged China…

items.title: China tells citizens not to visit Japan as Taiwan row grows
items.standfirst: China has advised its citizens to avoid travelling to Japan, following a diplomatic feud sparked by remarks from Tokyo's new premier about a hypothetical attack on Taiwan. Details and analysis with James Simms, FRANCE 24 correspondent in Tokyo.
items.content: China has advised its citizens to avoid travelling to Japan, following a diplomatic feud sparked by remarks from Tokyo's new premier about a hypothetical attack on Taiwan. Details and analysis with James Simms, FRANCE 24 correspondent in Tokyo.

items.content: China asks citizens to avoid travelling to Japan, following diplomatic feud due to remarks by Tokyo's new premier.

items.title: China advises against travel to Japan amid escalating row over PM’s Taiwan comments
items.standfirst: Sanae Takaichi says the use of force against Taiwan could warrant a military response from TokyoChina has advised its citizens to avoid travelling to Japan, escalating a diplomatic feud sparked by comments from Tokyo’s new prime minister about a hypothetical attack on Taiwan.Sanae Takaichi told Japan’s parliament on 7 November that the use of force against the self-ruled island claimed by China could warrant a military response from Tokyo. Japan has since said its position on Taiwan – just 100km from the nearest Japanese island – is unchanged. Continue reading...
items.content: Sanae Takaichi says the use of force against Taiwan could warrant a military response from TokyoChina has advised its citizens to avoid travelling to Japan, escalating a diplomatic feud sparked by comments from Tokyo’s new prime minister about a hypothetical attack on Taiwan.Sanae Takaichi told Japan’s parliament on 7 November that the use of force against the self-ruled island claimed by China could warrant a military response from Tokyo. Japan has since said its position on Taiwan – just 100km from the nearest Japanese island – is unchanged. Continue reading...

items.title: China urges citizens not to visit Japan over Taiwan row
items.standfirst: Japanese PM Sanae Takaichi had suggested Tokyo could take military action if Beijing attacked Taiwan.
items.content: Japanese PM Sanae Takaichi had suggested Tokyo could take military action if Beijing attacked Taiwan.

items.title: A 'dirty neck,' 'evil witch': Why a furious China is unleashing on Japan's new leader
items.standfirst: China and Japan are locked in a furious diplomatic spat after Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi said an attack on Taiwan could draw a military response from Tokyo.
items.content: China and Japan are locked in a furious diplomatic spat after Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi said an attack on Taiwan could draw a military response from Tokyo.

Japan's leader suggested military action if China attacked Taiwan.

clusters.title: Nine killed in blast at police station in Indian-administered Kashmir
clusters.neutral_headline: Nine Killed in Police Station Blast in Kashmir

items.title: Nine killed in blast at police station in Indian-administered Kashmir
items.standfirst: An explosion at a police station in Indian-administered Kashmir has killed at least nine people and injured 32 others.
items.content: An explosion at a police station in Indian-administered Kashmir has killed at least nine people and injured 32 others.

items.title: At least nine killed and 32 injured in Indian Kashmir police station explosion
items.standfirst: At least nine people have been killed and 32 injured after a cache of confiscated explosives detonated inside a police station in Indian-administered Kashmir.
items.content: At least nine people have been killed and 32 injured after a cache of confiscated explosives detonated inside a police station in Indian-administered Kashmir.

items.title: Nine killed in accidental blast at police station in Indian-administered Kashmir, officials say
items.standfirst: Police say the powerful blast severely damaged the police station and engulfed vehicles in flames.
items.content: Police say the powerful blast severely damaged the police station and engulfed vehicles in flames.

items.title: Blast from confiscated explosives at police station in Indian-controlled Kashmir kills nine
items.standfirst: The accidental explosion comes days after a deadly car blast in New Delhi which killed at least eight people near the city’s historic Red FortAt least nine people were killed and 32 injured after a cache of confiscated explosives detonated inside a police station in Indian-controlled Kashmir, police have announced.The blast occurred in the Nowgam area of Srinagar, the region’s main city, late on Friday while a team of forensic experts and police were examining the explosive material, said Nalin Prabhat, the region’s police director general. He ruled out any foul play, saying it was an accident. Continue reading...
items.content: The accidental explosion comes days after a deadly car blast in New Delhi which killed at least eight people near the city’s historic Red FortAt least nine people were killed and 32 injured after a cache of confiscated explosives detonated inside a police station in Indian-controlled Kashmir, police have announced.The blast occurred in the Nowgam area of Srinagar, the region’s main city, late on Friday while a team of forensic experts and police were examining the explosive material, said Nalin Prabhat, the region’s police director general. He ruled out any foul play, saying it was an accident. Continue reading...

ai_summary: An explosion at a police station in Indian-administered Kashmir killed nine.
Thirty-two others were injured in the blast at the police station.
The blast occurred due to the detonation of confiscated explosives.
Officials ruled out foul play, calling it an accidental explosion.
The police station suffered severe damage from the powerful blast.

items.title: Judge to approve $7bn settlement with OxyContin maker that requires Sackler family members to pay victims
items.standfirst: Deal would also require multibillionaire family to give up ownership of the Connecticut-based firmA federal bankruptcy court judge on Friday said he would approve OxyContin-maker Purdue Pharma’s latest deal to settle thousands of lawsuits over the toll of opioids that includes some money for thousands of victims of the epidemic.The deal overseen by US bankruptcy judge Sean Lane would require some of the multibillionaire members of the semi-reclusive Sackler family who own the company to contribute up to $7bn and give up ownership of the Connecticut-based firm. Continue reading...

items.title: Storm Claudia: Arctic winds to bring snow and -7C temperatures
items.standfirst: Major incident declared in Wales, with rescues and evacuations in Monmouth after river bursts its banksSnow could be on the way for parts of the UK with a cold snap set to arrive in the coming days in the wake of Storm Claudia, the Met Office said on Saturday.The storm had a significant impact in Wales where a major incident was declared, with dozens of people rescued from their homes or evacuated in the town of Monmouth following severe flooding when the River Monnow burst its banks. items.standfirst: The cost of protecting Oracle Corp.’s debt against default rose on Friday, after surging by the most since 2021 on Thursday, as jittery investors and lenders rush to hedge against the billions of dollars the software giant is pouring into artificial intelligence.

clusters.title: Mysterious plane carrying Gaza refugees lands in South Africa
clusters.neutral_headline: Plane carrying Gaza refugees lands in South Africa

items.title: Mysterious plane carrying Gaza refugees lands in South Africa
items.standfirst: South Africa's intelligence services are investigating who was behind a chartered plane that landed in Johannesburg with more than 150 Palestinians from war-ravaged Gaza who did not have proper travel documents and were held onboard on the tarmac for around 12 hours as a result, the country's president said Friday. Details by FRANCE 24 correspondent in Cape Town, Eunice Masson.
items.content: South Africa's intelligence services are investigating who was behind a chartered plane that landed in Johannesburg with more than 150 Palestinians from war-ravaged Gaza who did not have proper travel documents and were held onboard on the tarmac for around 12 hours as a result, the country's president said Friday. Details by FRANCE 24 correspondent in Cape Town, Eunice Masson.

items.title: South Africa to investigate ‘mysterious’ arrival of 153 Palestinians on plane
items.standfirst: Passengers held on runway for 12 hours after landing in Johannesburg without travel documentsSouth Africa will investigate the “mysterious” arrival of scores of Palestinians who were kept on a charter plane at Johannesburg for 12 hours by border police because they did not have travel papers, the president has said.A group of 153 Palestinians arrived at OR Tambo international airport in Johannesburg on a chartered Global Airways flight from Kenya on Thursday without departure stamps, return tickets or details of accommodation, according to the border authorities. Continue reading...
items.content: Passengers held on runway for 12 hours after landing in Johannesburg without travel documentsSouth Africa will investigate the “mysterious” arrival of scores of Palestinians who were kept on a charter plane at Johannesburg for 12 hours by border police because they did not have travel papers, the president has said.A group of 153 Palestinians arrived at OR Tambo international airport in Johannesburg on a chartered Global Airways flight from Kenya on Thursday without departure stamps, return tickets or details of accommodation, according to the border authorities. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A chartered plane landed in Johannesburg with Gaza refugees.

South African authorities are investigating the incident.

The plane carried over 150 Palestinians.

items.title: Pope Leo returns 62 artifacts to Indigenous peoples from Canada
items.standfirst: The Vatican returned 62 artifacts to Indigenous peoples from Canada, a historic restitution that is part of the Catholic Church's reckoning with its role in helping suppress Indigenous culture.
